HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 24, 1925.

ALUMNI TO GIVE
ANNUAL DANCE
Victorious or defeated, the
alumni will stage their annual dance for the undergraduates following t h e
Maryland game Thursday.
The affair will be held in the
ballroom of the Southern
Hotel. It will begin at nine
o'clock and end at a doubtful hour in the morning.
Preparations are in the
hands of Joseph Leopold,
'24, and a committee of that
class. The admission will be
less than that of the first
cotillion, two dollars a couple
and one dollar and a half
stag.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 24, 1925.

BEAT MARYLAND!
On Thanksgiving Day two years ago was played one of the
most thrilling football games in the history of Baltimore. But
as the twilight mists cast an ever thickening veil over the picturesque Baltimore Stadium, the ancient rivals, Hopkins and
, ,Maryland, had struggled to a deadlock.
Just one year later, the foes met again, each determined
.to capture the laurels of victory. But again nightfall witnessed no snake dance, nor did the horseshoe tremble with the
yells of victory—mad thousands. Hopkins and Maryland had
fought bravely, valiantly, heroically, but neither had attained
victory.
Another year has elapsed, and we find ourselves on• the
brink of another great struggle, the greatest struggle. Thursday's game will be great because all of the imprisoned enthusiasm of three years is straining for release. It will be great
, because a mighty battle of three years' duration—unless history repeats itself—will be decided.
We can beat Maryland. We feel it. We believe it. But
our team is facing a formidable foe in Maryland. This is no
time for passive belief. We must let the men who are fighting
for us know that we are with them; that we have faith in them;
that we know they are going to win; that we appreciate what
they are doing for us. We must be with them on every play.
Our -yells will help them to push forward or to hold. More
than in any other game of the year, the team needs our moral
'0113Foort.
We'will give it!
—A. R. E.
• 1

OLD STUFF
We do not know when the first college professor who
berated football flourished; we do not know when the first
'coach to make a heated reply was alive,—but we do know that
,it must have been years and years ago, in the first few hazy
years of football history. The argument which they started
,has waxed and wanted, has sounded loud, has sounded almost
not at all, but it has been kept lip to the present day, and at
present is attracting quite an unusual amount of attention.
The latest manifestation of the brawl is the vote carried
son by two enterprising Harvard undergraduates. "Would
Harvard trade President Lowell and other members of the
faculty for a good running backfield, or would Harvard refuse
to exchange one item of academic prestige for the best football team in history, with a herd of'newspaper propagandists
'thrown in?" is their query.
The fact that President Lowell and academic prestige won
hands down would indicate that at least one college has reached
a partial solution to the vexing problem of football versus
faculty.
However, the NEWS-LETTER is a bit curious. It wonders
if the undergraduate body, the coach, the team, and the alumni
would not be willing to part with one or two instructors for
a. victory over Maryland. The NEWS-LETTER fondly hopes that
no such attitude exists, but still it wonders, and is curiously
doubtful about the answer it would receive to such questions
as those asked at Harvard.
Oh, well, this is old stuff; we are signing off on this particular topic.

DORM
DOINGS
Last Thursday evening following
dinner the residents of the Alumni
Memorial Dormitory clos ely
hugged the walls of the Commons
Room to witness the Board of
Governors in action.
Dr. Oliver presided over the assemblage, and in opening, earnestly urged the residents to report all
complaints to the chairman of the
committee, whose function pertains to the matter in question.
He also stated that it was the desire of the Board of Governors to
settle all matters in a pleasant
manner without rules. The residents are to be ruleless, but not
unruly.
R. White reminded the residents
that it would be futile for the literary committee to purchase more
magazines, if the present supply
continues to disappear. The constant depression of the magazine
pile has become of a serious nature.

Like unto the leopard, the Barn.tormers' presentation of three
playlets last Saturday night in
the Playshop was spotty. Parts
were amusing and excellently portrayed, while other "spots" were
very noticeably amateurish.
We take into consideration,
however, the fact that in the three
playlets most of the parts were
played by men of little or no stage
experience and coached only by
members of the Barnstormers'
Club.
The program opened with a
melodrama, The Thief, by Frank
Packard, adapted by I. E. Rodgers, and coached by Ralph Townsend. George Hill, in the lead,
started out poorly in the prologue, but worked himself into the
part, improving as the action
progressed. H. D. Bilicovitch was
ideal as the standard crook play
pawnbroker.

class. The admission will be

stag.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 24, 1925.

BEAT MARYLAND!
On Thanksgiving Day two years ago was played one of the
most thrilling football games in the history of Baltimore. But
as the twilight mists cast an ever thickening veil over the picturesque Baltimore Stadium, the ancient rivals, Hopkins and
, ,Maryland, had struggled to a deadlock.
Just one year later, the foes met again, each determined
.to capture the laurels of victory. But again nightfall witnessed no snake dance, nor did the horseshoe tremble with the
yells of victory—mad thousands. Hopkins and Maryland had
fought bravely, valiantly, heroically, but neither had attained
victory.
Another year has elapsed, and we find ourselves on• the
brink of another great struggle, the greatest struggle. Thursday's game will be great because all of the imprisoned enthusiasm of three years is straining for release. It will be great
, because a mighty battle of three years' duration—unless history repeats itself—will be decided.
We can beat Maryland. We feel it. We believe it. But
our team is facing a formidable foe in Maryland. This is no
time for passive belief. We must let the men who are fighting
for us know that we are with them; that we have faith in them;
that we know they are going to win; that we appreciate what
they are doing for us. We must be with them on every play.
Our -yells will help them to push forward or to hold. More
than in any other game of the year, the team needs our moral
'0113Foort.
We'will give it!
—A. R. E.
• 1

OLD STUFF
We do not know when the first college professor who
berated football flourished; we do not know when the first
'coach to make a heated reply was alive,—but we do know that
,it must have been years and years ago, in the first few hazy
years of football history. The argument which they started
,has waxed and wanted, has sounded loud, has sounded almost
not at all, but it has been kept lip to the present day, and at
present is attracting quite an unusual amount of attention.
The latest manifestation of the brawl is the vote carried
son by two enterprising Harvard undergraduates. "Would
Harvard trade President Lowell and other members of the
faculty for a good running backfield, or would Harvard refuse
to exchange one item of academic prestige for the best football team in history, with a herd of'newspaper propagandists
'thrown in?" is their query.
The fact that President Lowell and academic prestige won
hands down would indicate that at least one college has reached
a partial solution to the vexing problem of football versus
faculty.
However, the NEWS-LETTER is a bit curious. It wonders
if the undergraduate body, the coach, the team, and the alumni
would not be willing to part with one or two instructors for
a. victory over Maryland. The NEWS-LETTER fondly hopes that
no such attitude exists, but still it wonders, and is curiously
doubtful about the answer it would receive to such questions
as those asked at Harvard.
Oh, well, this is old stuff; we are signing off on this particular topic.

complaints to the chairman of the
committee, whose function pertains to the matter in question.
He also stated that it was the desire of the Board of Governors to
settle all matters in a pleasant
manner without rules. The residents are to be ruleless, but not
unruly.
R. White reminded the residents
that it would be futile for the literary committee to purchase more
magazines, if the present supply
continues to disappear. The constant depression of the magazine
pile has become of a serious nature.

Like unto the leopard, the Barn.tormers' presentation of three
playlets last Saturday night in
the Playshop was spotty. Parts
were amusing and excellently portrayed, while other "spots" were
very noticeably amateurish.
We take into consideration,
however, the fact that in the three
playlets most of the parts were
played by men of little or no stage
experience and coached only by
members of the Barnstormers'
Club.
The program opened with a
melodrama, The Thief, by Frank
Packard, adapted by I. E. Rodgers, and coached by Ralph Townsend. George Hill, in the lead,
started out poorly in the prologue, but worked himself into the
part, improving as the action
progressed. H. D. Bilicovitch was
ideal as the standard crook play
pawnbroker.

SWIMMING CLUB
NOW BEING PLANNED
Negotiations have been
opened with prospective opponents in order to complete
the 1926 swimming schedule.
Although the team is practicing under difficulties a
worthy group of natators is
expected to bear the Black
and Blue in the coming contests.
Plans are under way to
have meets with Rutgers, Lehigh, and Swarthmore, who
must be met in the South
Atlantic championship race,
a n d Catholic University,
Navy, and Loyola. Loyola
will begin her swimming activities this year in a new
seventy-five foot pool.

Honored by France
Five Johns Hopkins professors
have been decorated by the Legion of Honor of France, according to information received Sunday. Four are members of the
Medical Faculty and one is a
member of the Philosophical Faculty.
